text: my phone rang I pick up the phone and on
the other end of the phone there's this
voice and it says hi I'm Steve Jobs and
I have a little company that I'd like to
tell you about that the company's called
Pixar and inside I went to myself what
is Pixar the early years were really
hard and really challenging there were
many times when I thought that we
wouldn't make it two months in I think
it came home and you know said to
Hillary my wife like I think I made the
biggest mistake of my career you know
and because it was like why would you
work for Steve Jobs who hasn't had a hit
in ten years and is being written off as
sort of a has-been in Silicon Valley for
Pixar a company in which burned through
50 million dollars of cash has nothing
to show for it
but you know I suppose I first began to
think that Pixar was going to break
through when Toy Story was released Toy
Story was obviously the first computer
animated you know feature film that had
ever been made and when Pixar embarked
on that project no one even knew if it
was possible because the technology for
doing computer animation at that scale
really didn't exist know then you were
able to say wow you know Pixar is on its
way and so what picks out did
brilliantly was learn how to harmonize
these conflicting forces that went into
the making of Pixar and so on the one
side you have this creative impulse to
do this incredible work and then pulling
against that are sort of business
imperatives like how rapidly are you
going to make films
so the executives so Steve Jobs Ed
Catmull myself we were not film makers
and so we made a decision that we were
going to let the creators be creative
and of course I would say it was an
extremely difficult decision to make
I think doing great creative work is a
little bit of a leap of faith when the
production goes wrong it's expensive so
when there's a crisis it's going to cost
money in the case of a animated feature
film it could cost 10 million dollars if
you make a big story change in the
middle which pretty much happens every
time and so it's in the moment of the
crisis that you're tempted you know as
an executive okay I need to step in
and take over now it takes a lot of
courage to say that you're going to
trust your creative people and and so
it's about finding the balance and Pixar
kind of Mars to debt I think
